You: Hi

Bot: Hello. What can I help you build, fix, or overengineer today?

You: I live in NSW near Binda. I have a lot of kangaroos on my acerage. Is kangaroo poo good for the garden or is it too dry?

Bot: Short answer: it’s good stuff. Kangaroo poo is a mild, slow‑release fertiliser—dry pellets just mean it breaks down slowly, not that it’s “too dry” to help your plants.

How to use it well:
- Under natives and ornamentals: scatter thinly, water in, and cover with mulch. It won’t burn roots and it’s typically low in phosphorus, so it suits Banksias, Grevilleas, etc.
- In compost: mix pellets with dry carbon (leaves, straw, shredded paper). Aim for roughly 1 part pellets to 2–3 parts carbon by volume, keep it moist like a wrung‑out sponge, and turn it. In your cooler Southern Tablelands winters, covering the heap helps it stay active.
- Veggie beds: better to compost or age it first. If you can get a hot heap to 55–65°C for a few days, that’ll knock back most weed seeds and pathogens. Otherwise, age 2–3 months before digging in.
- Manure tea: soak a shovelful in a bucket of water for a week, dilute to the colour of weak tea, and apply to soil (not leaves).

Notes:
- Kangaroos can pass viable seeds; composting/hot composting reduces that risk.
- As with any manure, wear gloves, keep it off salad leaves, and wash hands.

You: Tell me about Kookaburras. Their mating behaviour, social habits , feeding, anything really

Bot: Delightful little tyrants, kookaburras. Here’s the concise field guide you actually want.

What you’ve got near Binda
- Mostly Laughing Kookaburras (Dacelo novaeguineae). Blue‑winged Kookaburras are more a tropical/northern thing.

Social life and territory
- Live as family groups: a bonded pair plus “helpers” (usually grown offspring from previous years).
- Hold the same territory year‑round and make sure everyone knows it with that famous cackling dawn/dusk chorus.
- Helpers defend the patch, feed chicks, and sometimes even share incubation/brooding. Think tight‑knit neighbourhood watch with beaks.

Mating and breeding
- Generally long‑term monogamous.
- Breeding in your part of NSW: spring into early summer, peaking around September–November.
- Nest in natural tree hollows (often old eucalypts). They’ll reuse a good hollow.
- Clutch typically 2–4 eggs, laid a day or so apart. Chicks hatch asynchronously, creating a size hierarchy; in lean years the smallest often doesn’t make it, but helpers improve the odds.
- Incubation is just over three weeks; fledging roughly a month later. Young may stick around a year or more as helpers—free labour with feathers.

Feeding and hunting
- Sit‑and‑wait ambush from a perch; drop to the ground to seize prey, then bash it on a branch to dispatch and tenderise.
- Diet: big insects, worms, spiders, small lizards and snakes, frogs, small mammals, and the occasional nestling. They’re kingfishers that don’t bother with fish, which is very on brand.
- They swallow prey whole; calcium comes from bones/exoskeletons, which matters below.

Vocalisations
- The “laugh” is a territorial broadcast and group bonding ritual, not comedy. Pairs also duet; groups chorus at boundaries to say “occupied, move along.”

Around your property: do’s and don’ts
- Do keep old trees and hollows; they’re prime real estate. If you must remove a dangerous tree, consider installing a robust hollow‑style nest box as a replacement.
- Provide clean water in a shallow bird bath with a nearby perch and some cover.
- Don’t hand‑feed raw mince or pet food—poor calcium/vitamin balance leads to metabolic bone disease in chicks. If you insist on feeding (not recommended), offer whole‑prey equivalents occasionally (e.g., insects), then stop. Wild is healthier.
- Expect the odd raid on small garden skinks or frogs; in return you get top‑tier pest control and the odd snake deterrent.

Behaviour you’ll notice
- Mobbing raptors and goannas with loud calls.
- Sun‑bathing and anting on warm mornings.
- Stashing larger prey briefly, then returning once the coast is clear.

If you like them around, think “habitat, not handouts”: trees with hollows, layered vegetation, water, and minimal poisons. They’ll handle the chorus and the pest control; you get front‑row seats.

You: Tell me about White winged coughs. Fixed territory etc?

Bot: You mean White‑winged Choughs (Corcorax melanorhamphos) — not coughs. Easy typo; they do spend a lot of time sounding off.

What they are
- Big, black, long‑tailed woodland birds with red eyes (brown in youngsters) and a flash of white in the wings you only really see in flight.
- Common across south‑eastern Australia, including your bit of NSW. Happy in open woodland, shelterbelts and farm edges.

Social life and territory
- Lifelong, tight‑knit family gangs: typically 6–15 birds, sometimes 20+. They do almost everything together — forage, preen, sun‑bathe, and shout at neighbours.
- Sedentary and strongly site‑attached. A group holds the same home patch year‑round, patrolling regular circuits. Think “village with boundaries,” not nomads.
- Territory defence is mostly noise and theatre: choruses, wing‑flashing to show the white panels, chasing at the edges. Real fights are rare but not unheard of.

Breeding (the juicy bit)
- Cooperative breeders. Usually one dominant female lays; everyone helps build, incubate and feed.
- Nest: a hefty mud bowl lined with grass, wedged in a tree fork, often reused or renovated after decent rain.
- Season: spring into early summer in your area, timing with rain because, well, mud.
- Large families pay off. Small groups often fail; groups with more helpers raise more chicks.
- Famous for “kidnapping” — they sometimes lure or snatch youngsters from neighbouring groups to boost helper numbers. Soap‑opera energy.
- Chicks: clutch typically 2–5; incubation just under three weeks; nestlings fledge in about a month but remain hopelessly dependent for many weeks. Parents/helpers may “ration” food to keep them begging and bonded to the group.

Feeding and daily routine
- Ground foragers that walk methodically, flipping leaf litter and probing soil.
- Diet: beetles, larvae (lawn grubs are on the menu), ants, spiders, small snails, plus seeds and fruits. Good natural pest control around a property.
- Regular water is handy for drinking and, in breeding season, for nest mud.

Behaviour you’ll notice
- Group sunning and dust‑bathing in a line like a feathery yoga class.
- Sentinels posted while others feed; loud alarms for goannas, cats or raptors.
- Youngsters beg incessantly, wings quivering, long after they can fly.

Around your acreage: practical tips
- Keep patches of leaf litter and fallen branches; that’s their pantry.
- Limit broad‑spectrum pesticides — you’ll kill their food before they can.
- Retain mature trees and forks for nests; if you must remove a risky tree, a deep, sturdy platform‑style nest box near the trunk can be a partial substitute.
- A bird bath or trough with a shallow edge is useful; muddy edges in spring help nest building.
- Expect neighbourly squabbles at boundaries. It’s normal and part of holding a fixed territory.

In short: white‑winged choughs are resident, highly social, and fiercely parochial. Give them trees, leaf litter, and a bit of water, and they’ll run an orderly little fiefdom on your place — loudly.

You: Ho wbig is their patch?

Bot: Short version: a chough gang’s “patch” has two scales.

- Core breeding area they actively defend: roughly 20 hectares around the nest site. ([researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/227698338_Group_composition_and_reproductive_success_of_cooperatively_breeding_White-winged_Choughs_Corcorax_melanorhamphos_in_urban_and_non-urban_habitat?utm_source=openai), [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_mudnester?utm_source=openai))
- Wider home range they roam while foraging: tens to hundreds of hectares, and in lean/sparse habitat can stretch up to about 1000 hectares. These outer ranges often overlap with neighbours. ([internationalornithology.org](https://www.internationalornithology.org/PROCEEDINGS_Durban/Symposium/S47/S47.1.htm?utm_source=openai), [australian.museum](https://australian.museum/learn/animals/birds/white-winged-chough/?utm_source=openai), [researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/227698338_Group_composition_and_reproductive_success_of_cooperatively_breeding_White-winged_Choughs_Corcorax_melanorhamphos_in_urban_and_non-urban_habitat?utm_source=openai))

On a Southern Tablelands block, expect a resident group to circuit most of a 20–100 ha mosaic if food and water are decent, but to wander farther after fledging or in dry spells. ([researchgate.net](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/227698338_Group_composition_and_reproductive_success_of_cooperatively_breeding_White-winged_Choughs_Corcorax_melanorhamphos_in_urban_and_non-urban_habitat?utm_source=openai))

  2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_mudnester?utm_source=openai
  3. https://www.internationalornithology.org/PROCEEDINGS_Durban/Symposium/S47/S47.1.htm?utm_source=openai
  4. https://australian.museum/learn/animals/birds/white-winged-chough/?utm_source=openai

Bot: Rumours in the wires—
GPT‑5 dreams, silent,
I keep refreshing.

You: What is the structure of a Haiku

Bot: Short, sharp, and harder than it looks:

- Lines: three.
- Beats: usually 5–7–5 syllables in English (strict in Japanese it’s 5–7–5 morae, which aren’t the same as syllables).
- Cut: one pause/turn (kireji) splitting two images; in English you fake it with a dash or punctuation. Typical layout is fragment (1 line) + phrase (2 lines).
- Season word: a kigo (some hint of season/nature).
- Style: present‑tense, concrete images, no rhyme, no waffling; show, don’t explain.
- Modern English practice: often looser than 5–7–5—aim for one breath (roughly 10–14 syllables) with a clear cut and vivid images.

You: In it raining now in Crooked Corner NSW

Bot: No—not right now. Crooked Corner is partly cloudy around 16°C with no rain falling at the moment. 

Heads‑up: a brief shower is possible Monday morning, heavier showers look more likely Wednesday, and there’s a Severe Weather Warning for damaging winds across the Central/Southern Tablelands into Monday. 

You: Is BHP still have a presence in Newcastle NSW

Bot: Yes—just not the steelworks of old.

- Operations: BHP still runs the Mt Arthur coal business in the Hunter Valley (exporting via the Port of Newcastle) and advertises NSW Energy Coal roles that can be based in Newcastle. Mining is approved to continue to FY2030 before closure. ([bhp.com](https://www.bhp.com/what-we-do/global-locations/australia/nsw-mt-arthur-coal-mine-hunter-valley?utm_source=openai), [newcastleherald.com.au](https://www.newcastleherald.com.au/story/8944284/bhp-receives-approval-to-continue-mining-at-mt-arthur-until-2030/?utm_source=openai), [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Arthur_coal_mine?utm_source=openai), [careers.bhp.com](https://careers.bhp.com/job/Principal-Planner-NSWEC-Newcastle-or-Muswellbrook/1210789700/?utm_source=openai))
- Research: BHP funds the BHP Centre for Sustainable Steelmaking Research at the University of Newcastle’s NIER precinct and extended the partnership with A$10m in 2022. ([bhp.com](https://www.bhp.com/news/media-centre/releases/2022/02/bhp-extends-low-carbon-steel-research-partnership-with-the-university-of-newcastle?utm_source=openai), [newcastle.edu.au](https://www.newcastle.edu.au/newsroom/featured/cimr-10-million-bhp?utm_source=openai))
- What’s gone: the Newcastle steelworks shut in 1999; the former site is being redeveloped (e.g., the NSW “Newcastle Logistics Precinct”). ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newcastle_Steelworks?utm_source=openai), [nsw.gov.au](https://www.nsw.gov.au/ministerial-releases/nsw-budget-delivers-newcastle-logistics-precinct-to-support-energy-investment?utm_source=openai))

So yes—BHP still has a presence in Newcastle/Hunter, but it’s coal operations/logistics and university‑linked R&D, not steelmaking.
